fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We show in this text how the most important homology equivalences of fundamental Algebraic Topology can be obtained as reductions associated to discrete vector fields. Mainly the homology equivalences whose existence — most often non-constructive — is proved by the main spectral sequences, the Serre and Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequences. On the contrary, the constructive existence is here systematically looked for and obtained.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field reduces an ACC (C_k, d) to a smaller one, which can be explicitly described. Its cells are the critical cells in C_k. For the faces of a cell \sigma, we start with the faces d(\sigma) in the original ACC. Then we move every non-critical cell down along the discrete field lines, up to some sign flips, until we get to a critical cell.

Note that the field lines alternate between n- and (n+1)-dimensional cells, and we count the movement n – (n+1) – n as a single step. Also, discrete field lines can branch and merge, and the cells need to duplicate and move down every branch.

A discrete vector field (DVF) of degree p on an algebraic cellular complex is given by a collection of pairs of cells (\sigma, \tau), where \sigma is a regular face of the degree p cell \tau, standing for a vector pointing from \sigma to \tau, which we will write as \overrightharpoon{\sigma \tau}. We require that every cell appears at most once in these vectors.

A DVF naturally partitions the cells into three kinds: the sources, the targets, and the rest of the cells are called critical cells. This name comes from the analogy to Morse theory. Indeed there is a notion of discrete Morse function.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : {\textrm{id}} \to g \mathbin{\circ} f, such that \pi \mathbin{\circ} \iota = {\textrm{id}}, and \pi \mathbin{\circ} h = h \mathbin{\circ} \iota = h \mathbin{\circ} h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.
We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted {\pi_{\rho}} : C \to D, {\iota_{\rho}} : D \to C and {h_{\rho}} : C \to C, respectively.
We have a chain reduction C_* (X \times Y) \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow C_* (X) \otimes C_* (Y).

For every product of simplices \Delta^p \times \Delta^q, we put on the discrete vector field on \Delta^p \times \Delta^q. This DVF is admissible because the time a path stays in \Delta^p \times \Delta^q is bounded by a function of p and q. Then it is sent to a boundary cell.

Using , we get the required chain reduction. This is identical to the Eilenberg–Zilber reduction in literature, but the proof requires some combinatorics, and can be seen in Section 5.13 of Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. However, this formulation gives a much better computational performance.

This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. We assume basic familiarity with the classical aspects of the theory, although there will also be links within this forest to the relevant concepts.

fr:ul.fr:li: W-bar construction, simplicial principal bundles, twisted products by Simplicial objects in algebraic topology
composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex
